Headline: SEO Specialist @ Newline Tech | SEO Fundamentals, Digital Agencies Certification
Comment:
Eating your frog üê∏ first is crucial to how well your day turn out. It sets the tune for the day. 

A great perspective it is. No one perspective serves everyone though. 

Like you said. Some people prefer building momentum with easy first wins. 

Depending on where you're on this path, whatever serves you is advised. 

The key thing however is that you set your priorities such that whatever you set out to do is accomplished on the day no matter what happens.

Because THINGS don't happen suddenly. THINGS happen with little incremental inputs that over time gives you gargantum results. 

Block out pockets of action. What you make time for decides what you spend your time on.

Headline: Problem-solver at the intersection of ops, tech & people | Building systems that scale, workflows that work, and experiences that stick.
Comment:
Eating frogs is great advice, but maybe it‚Äôs time Coda, as a product, became the frog on your to-do list.

As a long-time power user, it‚Äôs honestly frustrating to watch these productivity philosophies get shared while core product development has stagnated for years. We‚Äôve been asking for better permissions, a mobile app that is in line with 2025, basic things. Not even "nice-to-haves" anymore. Shall I mention Microsoft Edge or "Coda Brain"?

Instead, we get more metaphors and fewer updates. The risk isn‚Äôt that users stop caring, it‚Äôs that they start leaving. And that slow bleed is harder to reverse than just sitting down and doing the work.
